Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702 Acquisitions and dispositions of assets.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702(1): 31A-5-701
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702(1)(a): 31A-5-701 An acquisition or disposition of asset is not subject to the reporting requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702(1)(b): For purposes of this part, an acquisition, a disposition, or the aggregate of any series of related acquisitions or related dispositions during any 30-day period, is material if it is:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702(1)(b)(i): nonrecurring;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702(1)(b)(ii): not in the ordinary course of business; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702(1)(b)(iii): involves more than 5% of the reporting insurer's total admitted assets as reported in its most recent statutory statement.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702(2)(a): An asset acquisition subject to this part includes every purchase, lease, exchange, merger, consolidation, succession, or other acquisition other than the construction or development of real property by or for the reporting insurer or the acquisition of materials for that purpose.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702(2)(b): An asset disposition subject to this part includes every sale, lease, exchange, merger, consolidation, mortgage, hypothecation, assignment, whether for the benefit of creditors or otherwise, abandonment, destruction, or other disposition.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702(3): 31A-5-701
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702(3)(a): 31A-5-701 The following information is required to be disclosed in any report filed pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702(3)(a)(i): the date of the transaction;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702(3)(a)(ii): the manner of acquisition or disposition;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702(3)(a)(iii): a description of the assets involved;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702(3)(a)(iv): the nature and amount of the consideration given or received;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702(3)(a)(v): the purpose of, or reason for, the transaction;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702(3)(a)(vi): the manner by which the amount of consideration was determined;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702(3)(a)(vii): any gain or loss recognized or realized as a result of the transaction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702(3)(a)(viii): the name of any person from whom the assets were acquired or to whom they were disposed.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702(3)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702(3)(b)(i): Insurers are required to report material acquisitions and dispositions on a nonconsolidated basis unless the insurer:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702(3)(b)(i)(A): is part of a consolidated group of insurers that uses a pooling arrangement or 100% reinsurance agreement that affects the solvency and integrity of the insurer's reserves; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702(3)(b)(i)(B): ceded substantially all of its direct and assumed business to the pool.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702(3)(b)(ii): For purposes of this section, an insurer is considered to have ceded substantially all of its direct and assumed business to a pool if:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702(3)(b)(ii)(A): the insurer has less than $1,000,000 total direct plus assumed written premiums during a calendar year that are not subject to a pooling arrangement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-702(3)(b)(ii)(B): the net income of the business not subject to the pooling arrangement represents less than 5% of the insurer's capital and surplus.


Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703 Nonrenewals, cancellations, or revisions of ceded reinsurance agreements.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703(1): 31A-5-701
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703(1)(a): 31A-5-701 A nonrenewal, cancellation, or revision of ceded reinsurance agreements is not subject to the reporting requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703(1)(a)(i): the nonrenewal, cancellation, or revision is not material; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703(1)(a)(ii): with respect to a property and casualty business, the insurer's total ceded written premium, on an annualized basis, is less than 10% of its total written premium for direct and assumed business; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703(1)(a)(iii): with respect to a life, annuity, and accident and health business, the total reserve credit taken for business ceded, on an annualized basis, is less than 10% of the statutory reserve requirement prior to a cession.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703(1)(b): For purposes of this part, a material nonrenewal, cancellation, or revision is one that affects:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703(1)(b)(i): with respect to a property and casualty business:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703(1)(b)(i)(A): more than 50% of the insurer's total ceded written premium; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703(1)(b)(i)(B): more than 50% of the insurer's total ceded indemnity and loss adjustment reserves;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703(1)(b)(ii): with respect to a life, annuity, and accident and health business, more than 50% of the total reserve credit taken for business ceded, on an annualized basis, as indicated in the insurer's most recent annual statement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703(1)(b)(iii): with respect to either property and casualty or life, annuity, or accident and health business:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703(1)(b)(iii)(A): an authorized reinsurer representing more than 10% of a total cession is replaced by one or more unauthorized reinsurers; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703(1)(b)(iii)(B): previously established collateral requirements have been reduced or waived as respects one or more unauthorized reinsurers representing collectively more than 10% of a total cession.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703(2): 31A-5-701
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703(2)(a): 31A-5-701 The following information is required to be disclosed in any report filed pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703(2)(a)(i): the effective date of the nonrenewal, cancellation, or revision;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703(2)(a)(ii): the description of the transaction with an identification of the initiator of the transaction;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703(2)(a)(iii): the purpose of, or reason for the transaction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703(2)(a)(iv): if applicable, the identity of the replacement reinsurers.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703(2)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703(2)(b)(i): Insurers are required to report all material nonrenewals, cancellations, or revisions of ceded reinsurance agreements on a nonconsolidated basis unless the insurer:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703(2)(b)(i)(A): is part of a consolidated group of insurers that uses a pooling arrangement or 100% reinsurance agreement that affects the solvency and integrity of the insurer's reserves; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703(2)(b)(i)(B): ceded substantially all of its direct and assumed business to the pool.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703(2)(b)(ii): An insurer is considered to have ceded substantially all of its direct and assumed business to a pool if:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703(2)(b)(ii)(A): the insurer has less than $1,000,000 total direct plus assumed written premiums during a calendar year that are not subject to a pooling arrangement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-5-703(2)(b)(ii)(B): the net income of the business not subject to the pooling arrangement represents less than 5% of the insurer's capital and surplus.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 31A - Chapter 6a - Service Contracts
****************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(1): (1)(a) "Home warranty service contract" means a service contract that requires a person to repair or replace a component, system, or appliance of a home or make indemnification to the contract holder for the repair or replacement of a component, system, or appliance of the home:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(1)(a): upon mechanical or operational failure of the component, system, or appliance;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(1)(b): for a predetermined fee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(1)(c): (1)(a) if:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(1)(c)(i): the person is not the builder, seller, or lessor of the home that is the subject of the contract; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(1)(c)(ii): (1)(a) the failure described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(2)(a): "Incidental cost" means a cost, incurred by a warranty holder in relation to a vehicle protection product warranty, that is in addition to the cost of purchasing the warranty.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(2)(b): "Incidental cost" includes an insurance policy deductible, a rental vehicle charge, the difference between the actual value of the stolen vehicle at the time of theft and the cost of a replacement vehicle, sales tax, a registration fee, a transaction fee, a mechanical inspection fee, or damage a theft causes to a vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(3): Chapter 5, Domestic Stock and Mutual Insurance Corporations; Chapter 14, Foreign Insurers "Mechanical breakdown insurance" means a policy, contract, or agreement issued by an insurance company that has complied with either
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(4): "Nonmanufacturers' parts" means replacement parts not made for or by the original manufacturer of the goods commonly referred to as "after market parts."
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(5)(a): "Road hazard" means a hazard that is encountered while driving a motor vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(5)(b): "Road hazard" includes potholes, rocks, wood debris, metal parts, glass, plastic, curbs, or composite scraps.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(6)(a): "Service contract" means a contract or agreement to perform or reimburse for the repair or maintenance of goods or property, for their operational or structural failure due to a defect in materials, workmanship, normal wear and tear, power surge or interruption, or accidental damage from handling, with or without additional provision for incidental payment of indemnity under limited circumstances, including towing, providing a rental car, providing emergency road service, and covering food spoilage.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(6)(b): "Service contract" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(6)(b)(i): mechanical breakdown insurance; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(6)(b)(ii): a prepaid contract of limited duration that provides for scheduled maintenance only, regardless of whether the contract is executed before, on, or after May 9, 2017.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(6)(c): "Service contract" includes any contract or agreement to perform or reimburse the service contract holder for any one or more of the following services:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(6)(c)(i): the repair or replacement of tires, wheels, or both on a motor vehicle damaged as a result of coming into contact with a road hazard;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(6)(c)(ii): the removal of dents, dings, or creases on a motor vehicle that can be repaired using the process of paintless dent removal without affecting the existing paint finish and without replacing vehicle body panels, sanding, bonding, or painting;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(6)(c)(iii): the repair of chips or cracks in or the replacement of a motor vehicle windshield as a result of damage caused by a road hazard, that is primary to the coverage offered by the motor vehicle owner's motor vehicle insurance policy; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(6)(c)(iv): the replacement of a motor vehicle key or key-fob if the key or key-fob becomes inoperable, lost, or stolen, except that the replacement of lost or stolen property is limited to only the replacement of a lost or stolen motor vehicle key or key-fob.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(7): "Service contract holder" or "contract holder" means a person who purchases a service contract.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(8): "Service contract provider" means a person who issues, makes, provides, administers, sells or offers to sell a service contract, or who is contractually obligated to provide service under a service contract.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(9): "Service contract reimbursement policy" or "reimbursement insurance policy" means a policy of insurance providing coverage for all obligations and liabilities incurred by the service contract provider or warrantor under the terms of the service contract or vehicle protection product warranty issued by the provider or warrantor.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(10)(a): "Vehicle protection product" means a device or system that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(10)(a)(i): installed on or applied to a motor vehicle; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(10)(a)(ii): designed to:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(10)(a)(ii)(A): prevent the theft of the vehicle; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(10)(a)(ii)(B): if the vehicle is stolen, aid in the recovery of the vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(10)(b): "Vehicle protection product" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(10)(b)(i): a vehicle protection product warranty;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(10)(b)(ii): an alarm system;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(10)(b)(iii): a body part marking product;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(10)(b)(iv): a steering lock;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(10)(b)(v): a window etch product;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(10)(b)(vi): a pedal and ignition lock;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(10)(b)(vii): a fuel and ignition kill switch; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(10)(b)(viii): an electronic, radio, or satellite tracking device.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(11): "Vehicle protection product warranty" means a written agreement by a warrantor that provides that if the vehicle protection product fails to prevent the theft of the motor vehicle, or aid in the recovery of the motor vehicle within a time period specified in the warranty, not exceeding 30 days after the day on which the motor vehicle is reported stolen, the warrantor will reimburse the warranty holder for incidental costs specified in the warranty, not exceeding $5,000, or in a specified fixed amount not exceeding $5,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(12): "Vehicle service contract" means a service contract for the repair or maintenance of a vehicle:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(12)(a): for operational or structural failure because of a defect in materials, workmanship, normal wear and tear, or accidental damage from handling; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(12)(b): with or without additional provision for incidental payment of indemnity under limited circumstances, including towing, providing a rental car, or providing emergency road service.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(13): "Warrantor" means a person who is contractually obligated to the warranty holder under the terms of a vehicle protection product warranty.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-101(14): "Warranty holder" means the person who purchases a vehicle protection product, any authorized transferee or assignee of the purchaser, or any other person legally assuming the purchaser's rights under the vehicle protection product warranty.


Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-102 Scope and purposes.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-102(1): The purposes of this chapter are to:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-102(1)(a): create a legal framework within which service contracts may be sold in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-102(1)(b): encourage innovation in the marketing and development of more economical and effective ways of providing services under service contracts, while placing the risk of innovation on the service contract providers rather than on consumers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-102(1)(c): permit and encourage fair and effective competition among different systems of providing and paying for these services.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-102(2): Service contracts may not be issued, sold, or offered for sale in this state unless the provider has complied with this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-102(3): 31A-1-103 This chapter applies only to a service contract not otherwise exempted from this title by Section

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-104 Required disclosures.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-104(1): A reimbursement insurance policy insuring a service contract or a vehicle protection product warranty that is issued, sold, or offered for sale in this state shall conspicuously state that, upon failure of the service contract provider or warrantor to perform under the contract, the issuer of the policy shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-104(1)(a): pay on behalf of the service contract provider or warrantor any sums the service contract provider or warrantor is legally obligated to pay according to the service contract provider's or warrantor's contractual obligations under the service contract or a vehicle protection product warranty issued or sold by the service contract provider or warrantor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-104(1)(b): provide the service which the service contract provider is legally obligated to perform, according to the service contract provider's contractual obligations under the service contract issued or sold by the service contract provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-104(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-104(2)(a): A service contract may not be issued, sold, or offered for sale in this state unless the service contract contains the following statements in substantially the following form:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-104(2)(a)(i): "Obligations of the provider under this service contract are guaranteed under a service contract reimbursement insurance policy. Should the provider fail to pay or provide service on any claim within 60 days after proof of loss has been filed, the contract holder is entitled to make a claim directly against the Insurance Company.";
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-104(2)(a)(ii): "This service contract or warranty is subject to limited regulation by the Utah Insurance Department. To file a complaint, contact the Utah Insurance Department."; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-104(2)(a)(iii): A service contract or reimbursement insurance policy may not be issued, sold, or offered for sale in this state unless the contract contains a statement in substantially the following form, "Coverage afforded under this contract is not guaranteed by the Property and Casualty Guaranty Association."
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-104(2)(b): A vehicle protection product warranty may not be issued, sold, or offered for sale in this state unless the vehicle protection product warranty contains the following statements in substantially the following form:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-104(2)(b)(i): "Obligations of the warrantor under this vehicle protection product warranty are guaranteed under a reimbursement insurance policy.  Should the warrantor fail to pay on any claim within 60 days after proof of loss has been filed, the warranty holder is entitled to make a claim directly against the Insurance Company.";
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-104(2)(b)(ii): "This vehicle protection product warranty is subject to limited regulation by the Utah Insurance Department.  To file a complaint, contact the Utah Insurance Department."; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-104(2)(b)(iii): as applicable:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-104(2)(b)(iii)(A): "The warrantor under this vehicle protection product warranty will reimburse the warranty holder as specified in the warranty upon the theft of the vehicle."; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-104(2)(b)(iii)(B): "The warrantor under this vehicle protection product warranty will reimburse the warranty holder as specified in the warranty and at the end of the time period specified in the warranty if, following the theft of the vehicle, the stolen vehicle is not recovered within a time period specified in the warranty, not to exceed 30 days after the day on which the vehicle is reported stolen."
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-104(2)(c): A vehicle protection product warranty, or reimbursement insurance policy, may not be issued, sold, or offered for sale in this state unless the warranty contains a statement in substantially the following form, "Coverage afforded under this warranty is not guaranteed by the Property and Casualty Guaranty Association."
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-104(3): 31A-21-303; 31A-21-305
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-104(3)(a): 31A-21-303; 31A-21-305 A service contract and a vehicle protection product warranty shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-104(3)(a)(i): conspicuously state the name, address, and a toll free claims service telephone number of the reimbursement insurer;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-104(3)(a)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-104(3)(a)(ii)(A): identify the service contract provider, the seller, and the service contract holder; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-104(3)(a)(ii)(B): identify the warrantor, the seller, and the warranty holder;

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-105(2)(b): deliberately omit a material statement that would be considered misleading if omitted, in connection with the sale, offer to sell, or advertisement of a service contract or vehicle protection product.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-105(3): A bank, savings and loan association, insurance company, or other lending institution may not require the purchase of a service contract as a condition of a loan.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-105(4)(b): a debt cancellation agreement, unless licensed by the commissioner; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-105(4)(c): a debt suspension agreement, unless licensed by the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-105(5): A warrantor or the warrantor's representative may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-105(5)(a): require the purchase of a vehicle protection product as a condition of the financing, lease, or purchase of a motor vehicle; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-105(5)(b): sell a vehicle protection product to a consumer before providing the consumer, for review, a copy of the vehicle protection product warranty that is filed with the Department of Insurance.

------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-106(1)(a): All service contract providers shall keep accurate accounts, books, and records concerning transactions regulated under this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-106(1)(c): Service contract providers shall retain all records pertaining to each service contract holder for at least three years after the specified period of coverage has expired.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------
The issuer of a reimbursement insurance policy may not cancel the policy until a notice of cancellation in accordance with Section

Providers under this chapter are considered to be the agent of the issuer of the reimbursement insurance for purposes of Section

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-109 Enforcement provisions.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-109(1): If the commissioner finds, as part of an adjudicative proceeding under Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act, that a person has violated any provision of this chapter, the commissioner may take one or more of the following actions:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-109(1)(a): revoke a registration issued under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-109(1)(b): suspend, for a specified period of 12 months or less, a registration issued under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-109(1)(c): deny an application for a registration under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-109(1)(d): assess a forfeiture equal to two times the amount of any profit gained from the violation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-109(1)(e): assess an additional forfeiture not to exceed $1,000 per violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-109(2): If the violations are continuing, or are of a serious nature, or a person's business practices in connection with the solicitation, sale, offering for sale, or performance under a service contract subject to this chapter, constitute a danger to the legitimate interests of consumers or the public, the commissioner may enjoin the person from soliciting, selling, or offering to sell service contracts in this state either permanently or for a stated period of time.

--------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-110(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act Pursuant to
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-110(2): 31A-1-103(3) The commissioner may by rule or order, after a hearing, exempt certain service contract providers or service contract providers for a specific class of service contracts that are not otherwise exempt under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-111 Vehicle protection product warranty requirements.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-111(1): A warrantor shall make a reimbursement promised under a vehicle protection product warranty as specified in the warranty, regardless of, and not contingent upon, the payment of a benefit provided for under the warranty holder's primary vehicle insurance or any other contract.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-111(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-111(2)(a): If a vehicle protection product is represented as preventing the theft of a vehicle, the vehicle protection product warranty shall, at a minimum, provide for reimbursement of damage a theft causes to the motor vehicle up to $5,000, if the vehicle is recovered within the time period specified in the warranty following the theft of the vehicle, not to exceed 30 days after the day on which the vehicle is reported stolen.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6a-111(2)(b): If a vehicle protection product is represented as aiding in the recovery of a stolen vehicle, the vehicle protection product warranty shall provide for reimbursement of the vehicle up to $5,000, if the vehicle is not recovered within the time period specified in the warranty following the theft of the vehicle, not to exceed 30 days after the day on which the vehicle is reported stolen.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 31A - Chapter 6b - Guaranteed Asset Protection Waiver Act
*************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Guaranteed Asset Protection Waiver Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(1): This section defines a term only for purposes of this chapter.  A term defined in this section is not required to be used in a guaranteed asset protection waiver.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2): (2)(d); 31A-6b-204 For purposes of this chapter:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(a): "Administrative functions" includes providing:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(a)(i): document development, processing, and management;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(a)(ii): data processing and support;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(a)(iii): compliance services;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(a)(iv): waiver fee processing;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(a)(v): benefit determination;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(a)(vi): technology support; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(a)(vii): personnel support.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(b): "Administrator" means a person who provides administrative functions related to a guaranteed asset protection waiver.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(c): "Borrower" means a person who under a finance agreement is:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(c)(i): a debtor;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(c)(ii): a retail buyer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(c)(iii): a lessee.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(d): (2)(d) "Creditor" means a person who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(d)(i): a lender in a loan or credit transaction;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(d)(ii): a retail seller of a vehicle that provides credit to a retail buyer of the vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(d)(iii): a lessor in a lease transaction;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(d)(iv): a seller in a commercial retail installment transaction; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(d)(v): (2)(d) an assignee of a person listed in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(e): "Finance agreement" means one or more of the following for the purchase or lease of a vehicle:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(e)(i): a loan;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(e)(ii): a retail installment sales contract; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(e)(iii): a lease.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(f): "Guaranteed asset protection waiver" means a contract for a separate charge:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(f)(i): under which a creditor agrees to waive all or part of the amounts due on a borrower's finance agreement if a vehicle is subject to:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(f)(i)(A): a total physical damage loss; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(f)(i)(B): unrecovered theft; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(f)(ii): that is made part of a finance agreement, even if the guaranteed asset protection waiver is stated in a separate addendum to the finance agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(g): "Preliminary period" means a time period that:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(g)(i): begins the day on which a guaranteed asset protection waiver becomes effective; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(g)(ii): ends the last day on which a borrower may cancel the guaranteed asset protection waiver with a full refund if no benefits have been provided.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(h): 31A-6b-204 "Restricted account" means the Guaranteed Asset Protection Waiver Restricted Account created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(i)(i): "Vehicle" means a vehicle that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(i)(i)(A): self propelled or towed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(i)(i)(B): designed for personal or commercial use.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(i)(ii): "Vehicle" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(i)(ii)(A): an automobile;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(i)(ii)(B): a truck;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(i)(ii)(C): a motorcycle;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(i)(ii)(D): a recreational vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(i)(ii)(E): an all terrain vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(i)(ii)(F): a snowmobile;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(i)(ii)(G): a camper;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(i)(ii)(H): a boat;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(i)(ii)(I): a personal watercraft; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-102(2)(i)(ii)(J): a trailer for a motorcycle, boat, camper, or personal watercraft.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-104 Severability.
----------------------------------------------
If a provision of this chapter or the application of a provision to a person or circumstance is held invalid, the remainder of this chapter shall be given effect without the invalid provision or application.  The provisions of this chapter are severable.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-204 Guaranteed Asset Protection Waiver Restricted Account.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-204(1): There is created in the General Fund a restricted account known as the "Guaranteed Asset Protection Waiver Restricted Account."
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-204(2): The restricted account shall consist of the money received by the commissioner under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-204(3): The commissioner shall administer the restricted account.  Subject to appropriations by the Legislature, the commissioner shall use the money deposited into the restricted account to pay for a cost or expense incurred by the commissioner in the administration, investigation, and enforcement of this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-301 General requirements for a guaranteed asset protection waiver.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-301(1): A person may not issue, market, sell, offer to sell, or otherwise provide a guaranteed asset protection waiver except in compliance with this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-301(2): If a creditor assigns, sells, or transfers a finance agreement, a guaranteed asset protection waiver remains a part of the finance agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-301(3): (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-301(3)(a): If a borrower finances or otherwise pays the charge for a guaranteed asset protection waiver, the creditor is liable to the borrower for a benefit due under the guaranteed asset protection waiver regardless of whether the retail seller, administrator, or other person who receives the payment from the borrower remits the charge.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-301(3)(b): (3) This Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-301(4): A creditor may require that a guaranteed asset protection waiver that the creditor issues be sold for:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-301(4)(a): a single payment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-301(4)(b): periodic payments.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-301(5): The following may not be conditioned on a borrower purchasing a guaranteed asset protection waiver:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-301(5)(a): the extension of credit;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-301(5)(b): a term of credit; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-301(5)(c): a term of the related vehicle sale or lease.


Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-302 Required disclosures.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-302(1): (2) A guaranteed asset protection waiver shall disclose the information described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-302(1)(a): in writing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-302(1)(b): in understandable language that is easy to read.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-302(2): 31A-6b-303; 31A-6b-303; 31A-6b-303 A guaranteed asset protection waiver shall disclose:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-302(2)(a): the name and address of the initial creditor and the borrower at the time the guaranteed asset protection waiver is executed;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-302(2)(b): if there is an administrator for the guaranteed asset protection waiver:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-302(2)(b)(i): the name of the administrator;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-302(2)(b)(ii): the address of the administrator; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-302(2)(b)(iii): a toll-free number to contact the administrator;

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303 Cancellation or termination of a guaranteed asset protection waiver.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303(1)(a): A borrower may cancel a guaranteed asset protection waiver in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303(1)(b): A borrower may not waive by contract the borrower's right to cancel a guaranteed asset protection waiver in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303(1)(c): A guaranteed asset protection waiver terminates on the day on which the related finance agreement terminates.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303(2)(a): A guaranteed asset protection waiver shall provide for a preliminary period of at least 30 days.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303(2)(b): If a borrower cancels a guaranteed asset protection waiver or if a guaranteed asset protection waiver terminates within the preliminary period, the borrower is entitled to a refund of the charge for the guaranteed asset protection waiver as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303(2)(b)(i): if benefits have not been provided, a full refund; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303(2)(b)(ii): if benefits have been provided, a refund to the extent provided for in the guaranteed asset protection waiver.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303(3)(a): If a guaranteed asset protection waiver is cancelled by the borrower or terminates after the preliminary period, to obtain a refund of any portion of the charge for the guaranteed asset protection waiver, the borrower shall request the refund:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303(3)(a)(i): in a writing provided to:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303(3)(a)(i)(A): the creditor;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303(3)(a)(i)(B): an administrator; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303(3)(a)(i)(C): another person designated in the guaranteed asset protection waiver;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303(3)(a)(ii): within 90 days of the day on which an event occurs that terminates the finance agreement if the refund is sought on the basis of termination of a finance agreement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303(3)(a)(iii): in accordance with any additional terms in the guaranteed asset protection waiver.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303(3)(b): If a guaranteed asset protection waiver is cancelled by the borrower or terminates after the preliminary period, but before the term of the finance agreement ends, a borrower is entitled to a refund:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303(3)(b)(i): of the portion of the charge for the guaranteed asset protection waiver that under the terms of the guaranteed asset protection waiver is considered unearned; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303(3)(b)(ii): subject to any other terms of the guaranteed asset protection waiver.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303(4): (4)(b); (4)
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303(4)(a): (4)(b) If the cancellation of a guaranteed asset protection waiver occurs as a result of any of the following, a refund may be paid directly to the creditor or administrator and applied as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303(4)(a)(i): a default under the finance agreement;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303(4)(a)(ii): the repossession of the vehicle associated with the finance agreement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303(4)(a)(iii): any other type of termination of the finance agreement or guaranteed asset protection waiver.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-6b-303(4)(b): (4) A creditor may apply a refund described in this Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8-102 Scope and purposes.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8-102(1): No person may operate an organization in this state without complying with and obtaining a certificate of authority under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8-102(2): The purposes of this chapter include to:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8-102(2)(a): provide for the establishment of health maintenance organizations which provide readily available, accessible, and quality comprehensive health care to their enrollees;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8-102(2)(b): provide for the establishment of limited health plans which provide readily available, accessible, and quality care to their enrollees;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8-102(2)(c): encourage the development of organizations as an alternative method of health care delivery; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8-102(2)(d): assure that organizations offering health plans within this state are financially and administratively sound and that these organizations are in fact able to deliver the benefits as promised.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8-105 General powers of organizations.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Organizations may:Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8-105(1): buy, sell, lease, encumber, construct, renovate, operate, or maintain hospitals, health care clinics, other health care facilities, and other real and personal property incidental to and reasonably necessary for the transaction of the business and for the accomplishment of the purposes of the organization;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8-105(2): furnish health care through providers which are under contract with the organization;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8-105(3): contract with insurance companies licensed in this state or with health service corporations authorized to do business in this state for insurance, indemnity, or reimbursement for the cost of health care furnished by the organization;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8-105(4): 31A-8-101; 31A-22-610.1 offer to its enrollees, in addition to health care, insured indemnity benefits, but only for emergency care, out-of-area coverage, unusual or infrequently used health services as defined in  Section
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8-105(5): receive from governmental or private agencies payments covering all or part of the cost of the health care furnished by the organization;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8-105(6): lend money to a medical group under contract with it or with a corporation under its control to acquire or construct health care facilities or for other uses to further its program of providing health care services to its enrollees;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8-105(7): be owned jointly by health care professionals and persons not professionally licensed without violating Utah law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8-105(8): do all other things necessary for the accomplishment of the purposes of the organization.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8-404 Annual audit of internal quality control.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Each organization shall prepare an annual report of the effectiveness of the organization's internal quality control.  The report shall be in a form prescribed by the commissioner after consultation with the director of the Department of Health, and shall be certified and signed by two officers of the organization.  The commissioner may at any time require an audit of an organization's quality control system.  The audit shall be performed by qualified persons designated by the commissioner.  Auditors shall have full access to all records of the organization and its providers, including medical records of individual patients.  The information contained in the medical records of individual patients shall remain confidential, and information derived from those records may not be used in a manner that could directly or indirectly identify an individual.  All information, interviews, reports, statements, memoranda, or other data furnished by reason of the audit and any findings or conclusions of the auditors are privileged and are not subject to discovery, use, or receipt in evidence in any legal proceeding except hearings before the commissioner or the director of the Department of Health concerning alleged violations of the provisions of this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8-405 Confidentiality of medical records and audits.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Unless a court orders otherwise, the department shall treat the following records and information as confidential and prevent their disclosure to the public:Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8-405(1): the medical records of enrollees of an organization; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8-405(2): 31A-8-404 the annual audits performed under Section

Utah Code Annotated - Title 31A - Chapter 8a - Health Discount Program Consumer Protection Act
**********************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Health Discount Program Consumer Protection Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-102(1): "Fee" means any periodic charge for use of a discount program.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-102(2): 78B-3-403 "Health care provider" means a health care provider as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-102(2)(a): is practicing within the scope of the provider's license; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-102(2)(b): has agreed either directly or indirectly, by contract or any other arrangement with a health discount program operator, to provide a discount to enrollees of a health discount program.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-102(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-102(3)(a): "Health discount program" means a business arrangement or contract in which a person pays fees, dues, charges, or other consideration in exchange for a program that provides access to health care providers who agree to provide a discount for health care services.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-102(3)(b): "Health discount program" does not include a program that does not charge a membership fee or require other consideration from the member to use the program's discounts for health services.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-102(4): "Health discount program marketer" means a person, including a private label entity, that markets, promotes, sells, or distributes a health discount program but does not operate a health discount program.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-102(5): "Health discount program operator" means a person that provides a health discount program by entering into a contract or agreement, directly or indirectly, with a person or persons in this state who agree to provide discounts for health care services to enrollees of the health discount program and determines the charge to members.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-102(6): "Marketing" means making or causing to be made any communication that contains information that relates to a product or contract regulated under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-102(7): "Value-added benefit" means a discount offering with no additional charge made by a health insurer or health maintenance organization that is licensed under this title, in connection with existing contracts with the health insurer or health maintenance organization.


Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-103 Scope and purposes.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-103(1): A person shall comply with the provisions of this chapter if the person operates a health discount program in this state.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-204 Advertising restrictions and requirements.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-204(1): An operator of a health discount program may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-204(1)(a): use any form of words or terms that may confuse health discount programs with other types of  health insurance in advertising or marketing such as "health plan," "health benefit plan," "coverage," "copay," "copayments," "preexisting conditions," "guaranteed issue," "premium," and "preferred provider";
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-204(1)(b): use other terms as designated by the commissioner by administrative rule in advertisement or marketing that could reasonably mislead a consumer to believe that a discount health program is any other form of health insurance; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-204(1)(c): refer to sales representatives as "agents," "producers," or "consultants."
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-204(2): A health discount program operator:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-204(2)(a): shall have a written agreement with any marketer of the health discount program prior to marketing, selling, promoting, or distributing the health discount programs;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-204(2)(b): shall file with the commissioner all advertisement, marketing materials, brochures, and discount programs prior to their use or distribution; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-204(2)(c): shall make the following disclosures:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-204(2)(c)(i): in writing in at least 10-point type and bolded; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-204(2)(c)(ii): with any marketing or advertising to the public and with any enrollment forms given to an enrollee:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-204(2)(c)(ii)(A): the program is not a health insurance policy;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-204(2)(c)(ii)(B): the program provides discounts only at certain health care providers for health care services;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-204(2)(c)(ii)(C): the program holder is obligated to pay for all health care services but will receive a discount from those health care providers who have contracted with the health discount program; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-204(2)(c)(ii)(D): the corporate name and the location of the health discount program operator.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-204(3): A health discount program operator or marketer who sells the health discount program with another product shall provide the consumer a written itemization of the fees of the health discount program separate from any fees or charges for the other product, which can be purchased separately.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-8a-205(3)(b)(i): if via the Internet, the online application form is completed and sent by the purchaser to the health discount program operator;

Utah Code Annotated - Title 31A - Chapter 9 - Insurance Fraternals

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-101 Definitions.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-101(1): (1)(a)(ii); 31A-9-403 As used in this chapter:

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-101(1)(a)(ii): exists solely for:

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-101(1)(a)(ii)(B): any lawful social, intellectual, educational, charitable, benevolent, moral, fraternal, patriotic, or religious purpose for the benefit of its members or the public, carried on through voluntary activity of its members in their local lodges or through institutional programs of the fraternal or its local lodges;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-101(1)(a)(iii): has a lodge system;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-101(1)(a)(iv): has a representative form of government; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-101(1)(a)(v): provides insurance benefits authorized under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-101(1)(b): "Laws of a fraternal" include its articles of incorporation and bylaws, however designated.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-101(1)(c): (1)(a)(ii) "Lodge system" means one in which:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-101(1)(c)(i): there is a supreme governing body;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-101(1)(c)(ii): subordinate to the supreme governing body are local lodges, however designated, into which natural persons are admitted as members in accordance with the laws of the fraternal;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-101(1)(c)(iii): the local lodges are required by the laws of the fraternal to hold regular meetings at least monthly; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-101(1)(c)(iv): (1)(a)(ii) the local lodges regularly engage in programs involving member participation to implement the purposes of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-101(1)(d): 31A-9-403 "Representative form of government" means the fraternal complies with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-101(2): In any provisions of law made applicable to fraternals by this chapter, the technical terms used in those provisions are applicable to fraternals despite the use of other parallel terms by fraternals.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-101(3): 31A-1-301; 16-6a-102 The definitions in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-101(3)(a): "articles of incorporation";
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-101(3)(b): "bylaws"; and

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-102 Scope and purposes.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-102(1): 31A-14-210
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-102(1)(a): This chapter applies to all fraternals organized under the laws of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-102(1)(b): 31A-14-210 Except as expressly provided in this chapter and in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-102(2): The purposes of this chapter include:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-102(2)(a): providing a complete, self-contained procedure for the formation of fraternals;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-102(2)(b): assuring the solidity of fraternals by providing an organizational framework to facilitate sound management, operation, and regulation;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-102(2)(c): strengthening internal fraternal democracy through member participation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-102(2)(d): encouraging the fulfillment of the special purposes of fraternals.

---------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-202(3): A fraternal may organize lodges for children who are not old enough for membership, but who are to be covered by insurance.  Membership in local lodges is not required for those children, and they have no voting rights.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-213 Amendment of articles of incorporation.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-213(1): The articles of a fraternal may provide for amendment by the supreme governing body or by the board of directors, and may also provide for amendment by an affirmative vote of a majority of those members who vote in a referendum.  Only votes cast within 60 days from the date of mailing the first ballot by the fraternal are counted.  The timeliness of a vote is determined by the date of its mailing as evidenced by its postmark or other suitable evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-213(2): For five years after the initial issuance of a certificate of authority, proposed amendments of the articles shall be filed with the commissioner at least 30 days before the amendment is submitted for approval to the members or to the supreme governing body.  If the approval of the members or the supreme governing body is not required, proposed amendments to the articles shall be filed with the commissioner at least 30 days before their effective date.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-213(3): No amendment is effective until the articles of amendment are filed with the commissioner, together with a statement of the results of the voting on the amendment or a statement that no vote is required.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-213(4): 31A-9-402(1) Within four months after filing the articles of amendment with the commissioner, they shall be furnished to all members either by mail or under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-402 Communications to members.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-402(1): A fraternal may provide in its laws for an official publication in which any notice, report, or statement required by law to be given to members, including a notice of election, may be published.  Any required notice shall be printed conspicuously in the publication.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-402(2): The commissioner may by rule prescribe that copies of specified classes of communications published generally to members, including the official publication, be sent to the commissioner when they are sent to the members.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-402(3): If the records of a fraternal show that two or more members have the same mailing address, an official publication mailed to one member is considered to be notice to all members at the same address, unless a member requests a separate copy.


Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-403 Representative form of government.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-403(1): (2) A fraternal shall have a supreme governing body consisting either of:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-403(1)(a): (2) A board of directors is the supreme governing body of a fraternal. It consists of some directors elected directly by the members or by their representatives in intermediate assemblies under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-403(1)(b): Delegates elected directly by the members or at intermediate assemblies or conventions of members or their representatives, together with other delegates prescribed in the fraternal's laws form an assembly that is a supreme governing body of a fraternal.  A majority of the assembly shall be elected delegates, having at least two-thirds of the votes and with a sufficient number of votes to amend the articles or bylaws that can be amended without consent of the members.  The assembly, whatever designated, shall meet at least once every four years and shall elect a board of directors to conduct the business of the fraternal between meetings of the assembly.  The delegates making up the supreme governing body shall be elected on a plan that ensures approximately equal weight to each fraternal member's vote.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-403(2): The laws of a fraternal may provide that:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-403(2)(a): delegates to intermediate assemblies may represent geographical districts or lodges; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-403(2)(b): delegates may represent the members in defined classes determined on a reasonable basis; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-403(2)(c): the vote of a representative to an intermediate assembly is treated as the vote of the members represented.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-403(3): No votes may be cast by proxy.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-406 Removal of directors and filling of vacancies.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-406(1): 16-6a-820(4) A director may be removed from office for cause by an affirmative vote of a majority of the full board of directors at a meeting of the board called for that purpose or may be removed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-406(2): Any vacancy occurring in the board, including a vacancy created by an increase in the number of directors, may be filled by the affirmative vote of a majority of the directors then in office, although less than a quorum.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-406(3): If the laws of the fraternal provide that at least 2/3 of the directors are elected by the members, elected director vacancies may be filled by the board for the remainder of the terms for which there are vacancies.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-406(4): If the vacancy is to be filled other than by a regular election, the election by the board is effective only until a reasonable time has elapsed for choosing the director in that other manner.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-406(5): 31A-9-403(1)(a) If less than 2/3 of the directors are elected by the members, elected director vacancies may be filled by the directors only until the next succeeding regular election.  At that time, the elected director vacancy may be filled for the remainder of the term for which there is a vacancy.  A director elected under this section to fill the unexpired term of an elected director is an elected director within the meaning of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-406(6): If the board ceases to exist, the commissioner shall arrange the necessary procedures for holding elections to create a new board.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-502 Voluntary dissolution of solvent domestic fraternals.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-502(2): (1); 31A-27a-207 The proposal for voluntary dissolution shall be filed with the commissioner at least 60 days prior to the submission of that proposal to the supreme governing body or the members.  The commissioner may require the submission of additional information necessary to establish the financial condition of the fraternal or other facts relevant to the proposed dissolution.  If the supreme governing body or the members adopt the resolution to dissolve, by a majority of those voting or a larger number as required by the laws of the fraternal, the commissioner shall, within 30 days after the adoption of the resolution, begin to examine the fraternal.  The commissioner shall approve the dissolution unless the commissioner finds, after the examination and a hearing, that it is insolvent or may become insolvent in the process of dissolution.  Upon approval, the fraternal may provide for a transfer to other fraternals approved by the commissioner of all its obligations under insurance policies and then may dissolve under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-601 Tax exemption.
----------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-602 Fraternal expenditures and activities.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-602(1): 31A-9-101(1)(a)(ii)(B) Every fraternal shall report to the commissioner the information required by the commissioner concerning expenditures made by the fraternal and other activities and programs of the fraternal or its members in fulfillment of the purposes of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-602(2): Title 16, Chapter 10a, Utah Revised Business Corporation Act A fraternal may create, maintain, and operate social, intellectual, educational, charitable, benevolent, moral, fraternal, patriotic, or religious institutions for the benefit of its members or their families or dependents or for children insured by the fraternal. For that purpose, it may own, hold, or lease real or personal property within or outside of this state. All that property is reported in the annual statement or an appendix to it, but the property is given only a nominal value in the statement. No profit may be made on those institutions, but the income and expenditures are reported separately in, or as an appendix to, the annual statement. Any of these institutions may be separately incorporated under
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-602(3): The fraternal may not own or operate a funeral or undertaking establishment.


Utah Code Annotated § 31A-9-603 Exemption of fraternal benefits.
----------------------------------------------------------------
No money or other benefit, charity, relief, or aid to be paid, provided, or rendered by any domestic or nondomestic fraternal is liable to attachment, garnishment, or other process, or may be seized, taken, appropriated, or applied by any legal or equitable process or operation of law to pay a debt or liability of a member or beneficiary, or any other person who may have a right to them, either before or after their payment by the fraternal.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 31A - Chapter 10 - Annuities
********************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-10-201 Definition.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 31A-10-201(1): Chapter 5, Domestic Stock and Mutual Insurance Corporations; Chapter 14, Foreign Insurers "Nontraditional  insurer" means an insurer incorporated under
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-10-201(1)(a): exists for the purpose of aiding and strengthening the following by providing them with annuities:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-10-201(1)(a)(i): nonprofit entities;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-10-201(1)(a)(ii): employees of nonprofit entities;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-10-201(1)(a)(iii): governmental entities; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-10-201(1)(a)(iv): employees of governmental entities;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-10-201(1)(b): issues only annuities and no other insurance product; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-10-201(1)(c): does not pay any benefit based on a guarantee as to principal, interest rate, return on investment, mortality, and morbidity.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-10-201(2): "Nontraditional insurer" does not include an insurer that provides annuities to persons other than:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-10-201(2)(a): nonprofit entities;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-10-201(2)(b): employees of nonprofit entities;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-10-201(2)(c): governmental entities; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-10-201(2)(d): employees of governmental entities.


Utah Code Annotated § 31A-10-202 Purposes of part.
--------------------------------------------------
The purposes of this part are:Utah Code Annotated § 31A-10-202(1): to provide for the continued operation in this state, subject to the provisions of this title, of nontraditional insurers providing annuities to the nonprofit entities and governmental entities of this state and their employees; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-10-202(2): to specify provisions which equitably deal with the operational, structural, and functional differences between nontraditional insurers and other insurers, without compromising the interests of policyholders.


Utah Code Annotated § 31A-10-203 Applicability of other provisions.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-10-203(1): Except as provided in this section, domestic nontraditional insurers are subject to the same provisions applicable to other domestic insurers, and nondomestic nontraditional insurers are subject to the same provisions applicable to other nondomestic insurers.

A guaranteed arrest bond certificate posted as a bail bond in a justice court is subject to the forfeiture and enforcement provisions of the charter or ordinance of the particular municipality which pertains to bail bonds.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 31A - Chapter 14 - Foreign Insurers
***************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-101 Purposes of chapter.
-----------------------------------------------------
This chapter's purposes are to:Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-101(1): protect insureds, creditors, and the public by providing adequate standards and an orderly procedure for the authorization of foreign insurers;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-101(2): subject foreign insurers doing an insurance business in Utah to the jurisdiction of the Utah commissioner and courts; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-101(3): provide Utah policyholders dealing with foreign insurers with regulatory protection equivalent to that provided to Utah policyholders dealing with domestic insurers.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-206 Commercially domiciled insurers.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-206(1): As used in this section, and except as to title insurers, the commissioner may consider a foreign insurer to be "commercially domiciled" in this state if:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-206(1)(a): during the three immediately preceding calendar years, the foreign insurer wrote more insurance premiums in this state than it wrote in its state of domicile during the same period; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-206(1)(b): during the same three-year period, the foreign insurer's gross premiums written in this state constituted 15% or more of the insurer's total gross premiums written in the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-206(2): (3); Chapter 16, Insurance Holding Companies; Chapter 17, Determination of Financial Condition; Chapter 18, Investments; Chapter 27, Delinquency Administrative Action Provisions; Chapter 27a, Insurer Receivership Act; Chapter 27a, Part 4, Liquidation; Part 5, Asset Recovery; Part 6, Claims; (3); (2) Subject to Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-207 Exclusive agency and management contracts.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-207(1): No foreign insurer licensed under this chapter may enter into or be subject to a contract that grants or surrenders the control or management of the insurer, unless the commissioner gives express approval of the contract. If amended, a contract previously approved under this subsection must again receive the commissioner's express approval.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-207(2): No nondomestic insurer may enter into any contract giving a person the exclusive or dominant right to produce the entire insurance business for the insurer in this state unless the contract is filed with and approved by the commissioner.  The contract is considered approved unless disapproved by the commissioner within 30 days after the date of filing.  The commissioner's disapproval shall be delivered to the insurer in writing, stating the grounds for the disapproval.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-207(3): (1); (2) The commissioner may not approve an exclusive management or exclusive agency contract under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-207(3)(a): subjects the insurer to excessive charges for expenses;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-207(3)(b): vests in a person any control over the general affairs of the insurer to the exclusion of its board of directors or officers;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-207(3)(c): extends for an unreasonable length of time; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-207(3)(d): contains other inequitable provisions which may jeopardize the security of Utah policyholders.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-211 Restrictions on foreign title insurers.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-211(1): An authorized foreign title insurer may only insure property in this state:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-211(1)(a): through an agency title insurance producer who is a resident in Utah; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-211(1)(b): if the authorized foreign title insurer has a bona fide office in Utah:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-211(1)(b)(i): that is under the direction and control of the authorized foreign title insurer;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-211(1)(b)(ii): for which the authorized foreign title insurer pays the expenses, including compensation of the employees of the bona fide office;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-211(1)(b)(iii): at which a person may request information about title services related to a real estate transaction for which the person is a party;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-211(1)(b)(iv): at which a person may deliver written communications to the authorized foreign title insurer as required by the real estate transaction for which the person is a party; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-211(1)(b)(v): at which a person may deliver escrow money related to a real estate transaction for which the person is a party.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-211(2): This section does not apply to reinsurance.


Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-212 Changes in business plan.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-212(1): 31A-14-201(2)(b)(xii) Within two years after the initial issuance of a certificate of authority to a foreign insurer by its domiciliary jurisdiction, the insurer may not substantially deviate from its business plan under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-212(2): (1) If the commissioner believes that the change proposed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-212(3): If the commissioner finds after a hearing that the application of the proposed change outside Utah would endanger the interests of insureds, creditors, or the public in Utah, the commissioner may revoke the insurer's certificate of authority unless the insurer agrees not to make the change.


Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-213 Transfer of business.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-213(1): A foreign insurer that intends to transfer to another person all or a substantial part of its insurance business in Utah by means of an assumption reinsurance transaction, a sale, or otherwise, shall report the proposed transaction to the commissioner not less than 30 days before the proposed effective date.  The commissioner may approve the transaction to take effect immediately.  Alternatively, the commissioner may defer the effective date of the transaction for an additional period not exceeding 30 days, by written notice to the insurer before the expiration of the initial 30-day period.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-213(2): The commissioner may, within the 30-day period or its extension, prohibit the proposed action if it would be contrary to the law or to the interests of insureds, creditors, or the public in Utah.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-216 Release from regulation.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-216(1): A foreign insurer authorized under this chapter is subject to regulation under the applicable provisions of the Insurance Code, unless it is released from regulation under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-216(2): A foreign insurer may apply for release from regulation by filing with the commissioner:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-216(2)(a): its certificate of authority;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-216(2)(b): a schedule of its outstanding liabilities from policies issued in this state to residents of Utah or on risks located in Utah, and from other business transactions in Utah;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-216(2)(c): a plan for securing the discharge of those outstanding liabilities; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-216(2)(d): any other information as reasonably required by the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-216(3): The commissioner shall promptly release the insurer from regulation if he finds all the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-216(3)(a): The insurer has stopped doing any new business in Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-216(3)(b): The discharge of existing liabilities to creditors in Utah is sufficiently secured.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-216(3)(c): The release would not otherwise be prejudicial to the interests of insureds or creditors in Utah or, if the insurer is an alien insurer and Utah is the state of entry into the United States, of all insureds and creditors in the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-14-216(4): Before deciding on the release, the commissioner may require the insurer to notify, at its own expense, all agents or other classes of potentially interested persons in a manner the commissioner prescribes, including publication of its withdrawal from Utah.  The notice shall advise affected persons to communicate to the commissioner any objections they may have to the insurer's release from regulation.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 31A - Chapter 15 - Unauthorized Insurers, Surplus Lines, and Risk Retention Groups
**************************************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-101 Purposes.
------------------------------------------
It is the purpose of this chapter to:Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-101(1): prevent evasion by unauthorized insurers of the regulatory and tax laws of Utah and protect Utah and its residents against loss from that type of evasion;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-101(2): subject unauthorized insurers and other persons doing an insurance business in Utah to the jurisdiction of the Utah commissioner and courts;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-101(3): protect authorized insurers from unfair competition by unauthorized insurers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-101(4): provide an orderly method, under reasonable and practical safeguards, for procuring insurance from unauthorized insurers.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-104 Direct placement of insurance.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-104(1): Subject to this section, any person seeking insurance may obtain it from an unauthorized insurer if no producer resident doing business in Utah is involved and if negotiations occur primarily outside Utah.  Negotiations by mail occur within Utah if a letter or other document containing insurance-related solicitations or negotiations is sent from or to a Utah address. Negotiations by telephone take place within Utah if one of the parties to the conversation is in Utah.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-105 Effect of contracts illegal because insurer was unauthorized.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-105(1): An insurance contract entered into in violation of this chapter is unenforceable by, but enforceable against, the insurer.  In an action against the insurer on the contract, the insured is bound by the terms of the contract as affected by this title and rules adopted under this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-105(2): (1) An insurance policy entered into in violation of this chapter is voidable by the policyholder who entered into the transaction without knowing it was illegal.  The policyholder may avoid the contract by notice to the insurer, if no insured has enforced the contract by an action under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-105(3): Chapter 27a, Insurer Receivership Act; Chapter 27a, Insurer Receivership Act Any person who assisted in the procurement of an illegal contract under this chapter, and who knew or should have known the transaction was illegal, is liable to the insured for the full amount of a claim or loss payable under the contract, if the insurer does not pay it. Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-108 Attorney fees.
-----------------------------------------------
In an action against an unauthorized person upon a contract of insurance issued in violation of this chapter, if the unauthorized person fails to make payment in accordance with the contract for 30 days after the payment is due and demand is made, and it appears to the court that the failure was without just cause, the court may allow the plaintiff a reasonable attorney's fee and may include the fee in any judgment that may be rendered in the action.  The unauthorized person's failure to defend this action is prima facie evidence that the failure to pay was without just cause.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-109 Investigation and disclosure of insurance contracts.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Whenever the commissioner has reason to believe that insurance has been effectuated by or for any person in Utah with an unauthorized insurer, the commissioner may, in writing, order the person to produce for examination all insurance contracts and other documents evidencing insurance with both authorized and unauthorized insurers and to disclose to the commissioner the amount of insurance, the name and address of each insurer, the gross amount of premium, and the name and address of any person who has assisted in effecting the insurance.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-110 Reporting of illegal insurance.
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-110(1): Every person investigating or adjusting any loss or claim on a subject of insurance in this state shall immediately report to the commissioner every insurance policy or contract connected with the investigation or settlement, which the person has reason to believe has been entered into illegally by any insurer not authorized to transact business in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-110(2): Every person acting as an insurance consultant shall immediately report to the commissioner every insurance policy or contract covering a subject of insurance in this state, which the consultant has reason to believe has been entered into illegally by an insurer not authorized to transact that type of insurance in this state.
