Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-201 Short title.
---------------------------------------------
This part shall be known as the "Risk Retention Groups Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(1): 31A-1-301 Notwithstanding Section
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(2): (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(2)(a): (2)(b) Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(2)(a)(i): any person who performs that work; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(2)(a)(ii): any person who hires an independent contractor to perform that work.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(2)(b): "Completed operations liability" includes liability for an activity that is completed or abandoned before the date of the occurrence giving rise to the liability.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(3): "Domicile," for purposes of determining the state in which a purchasing group is domiciled, means:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(3)(a): for a corporation, the state in which the purchasing group is incorporated; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(3)(b): for an unincorporated entity, the state of its principal place of business.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(4): "Hazardous financial condition" means that a risk retention group, based on its present or reasonably anticipated financial condition, although not yet financially impaired or insolvent, is unlikely to be able:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(4)(a): to meet obligations to policyholders with respect to known claims and reasonably anticipated claims; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(4)(b): to pay other obligations in the normal course of business.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(5): "Insurance" means primary insurance, excess insurance, reinsurance, surplus lines insurance, and any other arrangement for shifting and distributing risk which is determined to be insurance under the laws of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(6)(a): "Liability" means legal liability for damages, including costs of defense, legal costs and fees, and other claims expenses because of injuries to other persons, damage to their property, or other damage or loss to other persons resulting from or arising out of:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(6)(a)(i): any business, whether profit or nonprofit, trade, product, services, including professional services, premises, or operations; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(6)(a)(ii): any activity of any state or local government or any agency or political subdivision of any state or local government.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(6)(b): "Liability" does not include personal risk liability and an employer's liability with respect to its employees other than legal liability under the Federal Employers' Liability Act, 45 U.S.C. Sec. 51 et seq.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(7): (6) "Personal risk liability" means liability for damages because of injury to any person, damage to property, or other loss or damage resulting from any personal, familial, or household responsibilities or activities, rather than from responsibilities or activities referred to in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(8): "Plan of operation" or "feasibility study" means an analysis that presents the expected activities and results of a risk retention group, including at a minimum:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(8)(a): information sufficient to verify that its members are engaged in businesses or activities similar or related with respect to the liability to which the members are exposed by virtue of any related, similar or common business, trade, product, services, premises or operations;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(8)(b): for each state in which it intends to operate, the coverages, deductibles, coverage limits, rates, and rating classification systems for each line of insurance the group intends to offer;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(8)(c): historical and expected loss experience of the proposed members and national experience of similar exposures to the extent that this experience is reasonably available;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(8)(d): pro forma financial statements and projections;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(8)(e): appropriate opinions by a qualified, independent casualty actuary, including a determination of minimum premium or participation levels required to commence operations and to prevent a hazardous financial condition;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(8)(f): identification of management, underwriting and claims procedures, marketing methods, managerial oversight methods, investment policies, and reinsurance agreements;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(8)(g): identification of each state in which the risk retention group has obtained, or sought to obtain, a charter and license, and a description of its status in each such state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-202(8)(h): any other matters required by the commissioner of the state in which the risk retention group is chartered for liability insurance companies authorized by the insurance laws of that state.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-203 Risk retention groups chartered in this state.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-203(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-203(1)(a): "Board of directors" or "board" means the governing body of the risk retention group elected by the shareholders or members to establish policy, elect or appoint officers and committees, and make other governing decisions.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-203(1)(b): "Director" means a natural person designated in the articles of the risk retention group, or designated, elected, or appointed by any other manner, name, or title to act as a director.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-203(2): 31A-15-204
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-203(2)(a): 31A-15-204 A risk retention group under this part shall be chartered and licensed to write only liability insurance pursuant to this part and, except as provided elsewhere in this part, shall comply with all of the laws, rules, and requirements that apply to liability insurers chartered and licensed in this state, and with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-203(2)(b): Notwithstanding any other provision to the contrary, all risk retention groups chartered in this state shall file with the commissioner and the National Association of Insurance Commissioners an annual statement in a form prescribed by the commissioner and completed in accordance with the statement instructions and the National Association of Insurance Commissioners Accounting Practices and Procedures Manual.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-203(3): Before it may offer insurance in any state, each risk retention group shall also submit for approval to the commissioner of this state a plan of operation or feasibility study.  The risk retention group shall submit an appropriate revision of the plan or study in the event of any subsequent material change in any item of the plan of operation or feasibility study within 10 days of any change.  The group may not offer any additional kinds of liability insurance, in this state or in any other state, until any revision of the plan or study is approved by the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-203(4): 31A-15-204
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-203(4)(a): At the time of filing its application for charter, the risk retention group shall provide to the commissioner in summary form the following information:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-203(4)(a)(i): the identity of the initial members of the group;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-203(4)(a)(ii): the identity of those individuals who organized the group or who will provide administrative services or otherwise influence or control the activities of the group;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-203(4)(a)(iii): the amount and nature of initial capitalization;

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-206.5 Countersignatures not required.
------------------------------------------------------------------
A policy of insurance issued to a risk retention group or any member of the risk retention group may not be required to be countersigned.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-207 Purchasing groups -- Exemption from certain laws.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A purchasing group and its insurers are subject to all applicable laws of this state, except that a purchasing group and its insurers are exempt, in regard to liability insurance for the purchasing group, from any law that would:Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-207(1): prohibit the establishment of a purchasing group;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-207(2): make it unlawful for an insurer to provide, or offer to provide, to a purchasing group or its members insurance on a basis providing advantages based on their loss and expense experience not afforded to other persons with respect to rates, policy forms, coverages, or other matters;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-207(3): (2) prohibit a purchasing group or its members from purchasing insurance on a group basis described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-207(4): prohibit a purchasing group from obtaining insurance on a group basis because the group has not been in existence for a minimum period of time or because any member has not belonged to the group for a minimum period of time;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-207(5): require that a purchasing group have a minimum number of members, common ownership or affiliation, or certain legal form;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-207(6): require that a certain percentage of a purchasing group obtain insurance on a group basis;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-207(7): otherwise discriminate against a purchasing group or any of its members; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-207(8): require that any insurance policy issued to a purchasing group or any of its members be countersigned by an insurance producer residing in this state.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-209 Restrictions on purchasing groups.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-209(1): A purchasing group may not purchase insurance from a risk retention group that is not chartered in a state or from an insurer not admitted in the state in which the purchasing group is located, unless the purchase is effected through a licensed producer acting pursuant to the surplus lines laws and regulations of the state in which the purchasing group is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-209(2): A purchasing group that obtains liability insurance from an insurer not admitted in this state or a risk retention group shall inform each of the members of the purchasing group or risk retention group that have a risk resident or located in this state that:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-209(2)(a): the risk is not protected by an insurance insolvency guaranty fund in this state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-209(2)(b): the risk retention group or insurer may not be subject to all insurance laws and regulations of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-209(3): (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-209(3)(a): A purchasing group may not purchase insurance providing for a deductible or self-insured retention applicable to the group as a whole.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-209(3)(b): (3)(a) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-209(4): Purchases of insurance by purchasing groups are subject to the same standards regarding aggregate limits which are applicable to all purchases of group insurance.


Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-210 Purchasing group taxation.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Premium taxes and taxes on premiums paid for coverage of risks resident or located in this state by a purchasing group or any members of the purchasing groups are imposed and shall be paid as follows:Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-210(1): If the insurer is an admitted insurer, taxes are imposed on the insurer at the same rate and in the same manner and subject to the same procedures, interest, and penalties that apply to premium taxes and other taxes imposed on other admitted liability insurers relative to coverage of risks resident or located in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-210(2): If the insurer is an approved, nonadmitted surplus lines insurer, taxes are imposed on the licensed producer who effected coverage on risks resident or located in this state at the same rate and in the same manner and subject to the same procedures, interest, and penalties that apply to taxes imposed on other licensed producers effecting coverage with approved, nonadmitted surplus lines insurers on risks resident or located in this state.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-213 Effect of orders issued in U.S.  District Court.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An order issued by any district court of the United States shall be enforceable in the courts of this state to enjoin a risk retention group from soliciting or selling insurance, or operating in any state, in all states, or in any territory or possession of the United States, upon a finding that the group is in hazardous financial condition or financially impaired condition.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-213.5 Rulemaking.
----------------------------------------------
In accordance with

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-15-214 Severability.
----------------------------------------------
If any provision of this part, or the application of any provision to any person or circumstances, is held invalid, the remainder of this part shall be given effect without the invalid provision or application.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 31A - Chapter 16 - Insurance Holding Companies
**************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-101 Scope and purpose of chapter.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-101(1): This chapter applies to all persons doing an insurance business in Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-101(2): The purposes of this chapter include:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-101(2)(a): exercising surveillance over the acquisition of a domestic insurer, to ensure that in the process of making it part of an insurance holding company system, the interests of policyholders, shareholders, and the public are not harmed;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-101(2)(b): providing the regulatory monitoring of those intercorporate relationships and transactions among affiliates within an insurance holding company system that may affect the solidity of insurers;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-101(2)(c): controlling the payment of dividends that might affect the solidity of insurers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-101(2)(d): providing, in appropriate cases, recoupment of dividends paid.


Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.5 Subsidiaries of insurers.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.5(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.5(1)(a): A domestic insurer may organize or acquire one or more subsidiaries either:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.5(1)(a)(i): by itself; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.5(1)(a)(ii): in cooperation with one or more persons.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.5(1)(b): A subsidiary of a domestic insurer may conduct any kind of business or businesses and its authority to do so may not be limited by reason of the fact that it is a subsidiary of a domestic insurer.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6 Mutual insurance holding companies.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(1)(a): "Intermediate holding company" means a holding company that:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(1)(a)(i): is a subsidiary of a mutual insurance holding company;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(1)(a)(ii): directly or through a subsidiary of the holding company, holds one or more subsidiary insurers, including a reorganized mutual insurer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(1)(a)(iii): if the subsidiary insurers were not held by the holding company, a majority of the voting shares of the subsidy insurers' capital stock would be required under this section to be owned by the mutual insurance holding company.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(1)(b): "Majority of the voting shares" means the shares of a reorganized mutual insurer's capital stock that carry the right to cast a majority of the votes entitled to be cast by all of the outstanding shares of the reorganized mutual insurer's capital stock for the election of directors and other matters submitted to a vote of the reorganized mutual insurer's shareholders.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(2): 31A-16-103
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(2)(a): With the commissioner's approval, a domestic mutual insurer may reorganize by forming a mutual insurance holding company in which:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(2)(a)(i): in accordance with the mutual insurance holding company's articles of incorporation and bylaws, the membership interests of the domestic mutual insurer's policyholders become membership interests in the mutual insurance holding company; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(2)(a)(ii): the domestic mutual insurer is reorganized as a domestic stock insurance company.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(2)(b): 31A-16-103 The commissioner may approve a domestic mutual insurer's reorganization under this Subsection (2) if:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(2)(b)(i): 31A-16-103 the domestic mutual insurer's reorganization plan:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(2)(b)(i)(A): properly protects the interests of the domestic mutual insurer's policyholders;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(2)(b)(i)(B): is fair and equitable to the domestic mutual insurer's policyholders;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(2)(b)(i)(C): is approved by a majority of the domestic mutual insurer's policyholders present at any regular or special meeting of the policyholders at which a quorum is present; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(2)(b)(i)(D): 31A-16-103 satisfies the requirements of Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(2)(b)(ii): the initial shares of the reorganized domestic mutual insurer's capital stock are issued to the mutual insurance holding company or intermediate holding company; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(2)(b)(iii): at all times, the mutual insurance holding company or intermediate holding company owns a majority of the voting shares of the reorganized domestic mutual insurer's capital stock.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(2)(c): With the commissioner's approval, the mutual insurance holding company may allow in the mutual insurance holding company's articles and bylaws that a policyholder of a stock insurer that is or becomes a subsidiary of the mutual insurance holding company to be a member of the mutual insurance holding company.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(2)(d): The domestic mutual insurer:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(2)(d)(i): shall provide the domestic mutual insurer's policyholders notice of the reorganization plan and the related member meeting by first-class mail;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(2)(d)(ii): shall include in a notice described in Subsection (2)(d)(i), a copy of the full reorganization plan and all related plan materials;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(2)(d)(iii): may satisfy the requirement in Subsection (2)(d)(ii) by including with the notice of reorganization a URL link at which the policyholders can access the full reorganization plan and any related materials electronically; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(2)(d)(iv): shall provide a physical copy of the reorganization plan and all related plan materials to a policyholder upon request.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(3): 31A-16-103
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(3)(a): With the commissioner's approval, a domestic mutual insurer may reorganize by merging the domestic mutual insurer's policyholders' membership interests into an existing domestic mutual insurance holding company formed under Subsection (2), if:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(3)(a)(i): in accordance with the mutual insurance holding company's articles of incorporation and bylaws, the membership interests of the domestic mutual insurer's policyholders become membership interests in the mutual insurance holding company; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(3)(a)(ii): the domestic mutual insurer is reorganized as a domestic stock insurance company subsidiary of the existing domestic mutual insurance holding company or intermediate holding company.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(3)(b): 31A-16-103 The commissioner may approve a domestic mutual insurance company's reorganization under this Subsection (3) if:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(3)(b)(i): 31A-16-103 the domestic mutual insurer's reorganization plan:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(3)(b)(i)(A): properly protects the interests of the domestic mutual insurer's policyholders;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(3)(b)(i)(B): is fair and equitable to the domestic mutual insurer's policyholders; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(3)(b)(i)(C): 31A-16-103 satisfies the requirements of Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(3)(b)(ii): all of the initial shares of the capital stock of the reorganized insurance company are issued to the mutual insurance holding company or intermediate holding company; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(3)(b)(iii): at all times, the mutual insurance holding company or intermediate holding company owns a majority of the voting shares of the reorganized domestic mutual insurer's capital stock.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(3)(c): The commissioner may require, as a condition of approval, any modifications to the proposed merger the commissioner finds necessary for the protection of the policyholders' interests.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(4): 31A-16-103
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(4)(a): With the commissioner's approval, a foreign mutual insurer organized under the laws of any other state that would qualify to become a domestic insurer organized under the laws of this state may reorganize by merging the foreign mutual insurer's policyholders' membership interests into an existing domestic mutual insurance holding company formed under Subsection (2) in which:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(4)(a)(i): in accordance with the mutual insurance holding company's articles of incorporation and bylaws, the membership interests of the foreign mutual insurer's policyholders become membership interests in the mutual insurance holding company; and

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(4)(b)(i): 31A-16-103 the foreign mutual insurer's reorganization plan:

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(4)(b)(i)(B): properly protects the interests of the foreign mutual insurer's policyholders;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(4)(b)(i)(C): is fair and equitable to the foreign mutual insurer's policyholders; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(4)(b)(i)(D): 31A-16-103 satisfies the requirements of Subsections

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(4)(b)(iii): at all times, the mutual insurance holding company or intermediate holding company owns a majority of the voting shares of the reorganized foreign mutual insurer's capital stock.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(4)(c): After a reorganization contemplated by this Subsection (4), the reorganized foreign mutual insurer may:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(4)(c)(i): remain a foreign corporation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(4)(c)(ii): with the commissioner's approval, be admitted to conduct business in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(4)(d): A foreign mutual insurer that is a party to a reorganization plan may redomesticate in this state by complying with the applicable requirements of this state and the foreign mutual insurer's state of domicile.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(5)(a): As a condition of approval, the commissioner may require a mutual insurer to modify the mutual insurer's reorganization plan to protect the interests of the mutual insurer's policyholders.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(5)(b): If the commissioner determines reasonably necessary, at the reorganizing mutual insurer's expense, the commissioner may retain a third-party consultant to assist the commissioner in reviewing the mutual insurer's reorganization plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(5)(c): The commissioner has jurisdiction over a mutual insurance holding company or intermediate holding company organized in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(5)(d): Subject to the commissioner's approval, a reorganized mutual insurer or a stock insurance subsidiary within a mutual insurance company may issue a dividend or distribution to the mutual insurance holding company or intermediate holding company.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(6)(a): Subject to the provisions of this section, a mutual insurance holding company resulting from the reorganization of a domestic mutual insurer shall be incorporated in accordance with and is subject to the provisions of Chapter 5, Domestic Stock and Mutual Insurance Corporations as if it were a mutual insurer.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(6)(b): A mutual insurance holding company's articles of incorporation and bylaws are subject to commissioner's approval in the same manner as an insurance company's articles of incorporation and bylaws.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(7)(a): A mutual insurance holding company is:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(7)(a)(i): subject to Chapter 27a, Insurer Receivership Act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(7)(a)(ii): a party to any proceeding under Chapter 27a, Insurer Receivership Act, involving an insurer that is a subsidiary of the mutual insurance holding company as a result of a reorganization in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(7)(b): In a proceeding under Chapter 27a, Insurer Receivership Act, involving a reorganized mutual insurer, the assets of the mutual insurance holding company are assets of the estate of the reorganized mutual insurer for the purpose of satisfying the claims of the reorganized mutual insurer's policyholders.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(7)(c): A mutual insurance holding company may be dissolved or liquidated only by:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(7)(c)(i): prior approval of the commissioner; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(7)(c)(ii): court order in accordance with Chapter 27a, Insurer Receivership Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(8): 31A-5-506; 31A-5-506; 31A-5-204; 31A-5-217.5; 31A-5-301; 31A-5-307; 31A-5-505; 31A-5-509; 31A-5-203

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(10)(a): The ownership of a majority of the voting shares of a reorganized mutual insurer's capital stock includes indirect ownership through one or more intermediate holding companies in a corporate structure approved by the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(10)(b): The indirect ownership described in Subsection (10)(a) may not result in the mutual insurance holding company owning less than the equivalent of the majority of the voting shares of the reorganized mutual insurer's capital stock.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(11): 
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(11)(a): A mutual insurance holding company or intermediate holding company may not sell, transfer, assign, pledge, encumber, hypothecate, alienate, or subject to a security interest or lien the majority of the voting shares of the reorganized mutual insurer's capital stock.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(11)(b): An act that violates Subsection (11)(a) is void in reverse chronological order of the date the act occurred.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(11)(c): The majority of the voting shares of the reorganized mutual insurer's capital stock are not subject to execution and levy under Utah law.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(11)(d): The shares of the capital stock of the surviving or new company resulting from a merger or consolidation of two or more reorganized mutual insurers, or two or more intermediate holding companies that were subsidiaries of the same mutual insurance holding company, are subject to the same requirements, restrictions, and limitations described in this section that applied to the shares of the merging or consolidating reorganized mutual insurers or intermediate holding companies before the merger or consolidation.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-102.6(12): In accordance with Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act, the commissioner may make rules to implement the provisions of this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-104.5 Acquisitions involving insurers not otherwise covered.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-104.5(1): (1)(d)(i); (2)(b) The following definitions apply for the purposes of this section only:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-104.5(1)(a): "Acquisition" means an agreement, arrangement, or activity the consummation of which results in a person acquiring directly or indirectly the control of another person and includes the acquisition of voting securities, the acquisition of assets, bulk reinsurance, and mergers.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-104.5(1)(b): "Insurer" includes any company or group of companies under common management, ownership, or control.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-104.5(1)(c): "Involved insurer" includes an insurer that either acquires or is acquired, is affiliated with an acquirer or acquired, or is the result of a merger.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-104.5(1)(d): (1)(d)(i); (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-104.5(1)(d)(i): "Market" means the relevant product and geographical markets.  In determining the relevant product and geographical markets, the commissioner shall give due consideration to, among other things, the definitions or guidelines, if any, promulgated by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners and to information, if any, submitted by parties to the acquisition.  In the absence of sufficient information to the contrary, the relevant product market is assumed to be the direct written insurance premium for a line of business, such line being that used in the annual statement required to be filed by insurers doing business in this state, and the relevant geographical market is assumed to be this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-104.5(1)(d)(ii): (1)(d)(i); (2)(b) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-104.5(2): 31A-1-301(29)(d); (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-104.5(2)(a): This section applies to any acquisition in which there is a change in control of an insurer authorized to do business in Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-104.5(2)(b): 31A-1-301(29)(d); (3)(a) This section does not apply to the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-104.5(2)(b)(i): securities purchased solely for investment purposes so long as the securities are not used by voting or otherwise to cause or attempt to cause the substantial lessening of competition in any insurance market in this state;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-104.5(2)(b)(ii): 31A-1-301(29)(d) if a purchase of securities results in a presumption of control under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-104.5(2)(b)(iii): (3)(a) the acquisition of a person by another person when both persons are neither directly nor through affiliates primarily engaged in the business of insurance, if pre-acquisition notification is filed with the commissioner in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-104.5(2)(b)(iv): the acquisition of an already affiliated person;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-104.5(2)(b)(v): an acquisition if, as an immediate result of the acquisition:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-104.5(2)(b)(v)(A): in no market would the combined market share of the involved insurers exceed 5% of the total market;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-104.5(2)(b)(v)(B): there would be no increase in any market share; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-104.5(2)(b)(v)(C): in no market would the combined market share of the involved insurers exceeds 12% of the total market, and the market share increase by more than 2% of the total market;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-104.5(2)(b)(vi): an acquisition for which a pre-acquisition notification would be required pursuant to this section due solely to the resulting effect on the ocean marine insurance line of business; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-104.5(2)(b)(vii): an acquisition of an insurer whose domiciliary commissioner affirmatively finds that the insurer is in failing condition, and:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-104.5(2)(b)(vii)(A): there is a lack of feasible alternative to improving such condition;

The annual enterprise risk report shall be filed with the lead state commissioner of the insurance holding company system as determined by the procedures within the Financial Analysis Handbook adopted by the NAIC.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-110 Enjoining violations -- Voting securities acquired in violation of law or rule.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-110(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-110(1)(a): Whenever it appears to the commissioner that any insurer or any director, officer, employee, or agent of an insurer has committed or is about to commit a violation of this chapter or any rule or order issued by the commissioner under this chapter, the commissioner may petition a court for an order enjoining the insurer or a director, officer, employee, or agent of the insurer from the violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-110(1)(b): The commissioner may also request other equitable relief which the nature of the case and the interest of the insurer's policyholders, creditors, and shareholders or the public require.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-110(2): 31A-16-103; (2)(d)
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-110(2)(a): No security which is the subject of any agreement or arrangement regarding acquisition, or which is acquired or to be acquired, in contravention of the provisions of this chapter or any rule or order issued by the commissioner under this chapter, may be voted at any shareholders' meeting, or may be counted for quorum purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-110(2)(b): Any action of shareholders requiring the affirmative vote of a percentage of shares may be taken as though those securities were not issued and outstanding.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-110(2)(c): However, no action taken at that shareholders' meeting is invalidated by the voting of those securities, unless the action would materially affect control of the insurer or unless the court has ordered that voting invalidates the action.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-115 Revocation, suspension, or nonrenewal of insurer's license.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Whenever it appears to the commissioner that a person has committed a violation of this chapter that makes the continued operation of an insurer contrary to the interests of policyholders or the public, the commissioner may, after giving notice and an opportunity to be heard, suspend, revoke, or refuse to renew the insurer's license or authority to do business in this state for such period as the commissioner finds is required for the protection of policyholders or the public.  Any such determination shall be accompanied by specific findings of fact and conclusions of law.

--------------------------------------------------
The commissioner in accordance with

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-117 Judicial review -- Mandamus.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-117(1): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act A person aggrieved by an act, determination, rule, or order or any other action of the commissioner pursuant to this chapter may seek judicial review in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-117(2): The filing of an appeal pursuant to this section shall stay the application of any rule, order, or other action of the commissioner to the appealing party unless the court, after giving party notice and an opportunity to be heard, determines that a stay would be detrimental to the interest of policyholders, shareholders, creditors, or the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-117(3): A person aggrieved by a failure of the commissioner to act or make a determination required by this chapter may petition the district court in Salt Lake County for writ in the nature of a mandamus or a peremptory mandamus directing the commissioner to act or make a determination.


Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-118 Conflict with other laws.
----------------------------------------------------------
If any law or part of a law of this state is inconsistent with this chapter, this chapter governs.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16-119 Severability.
----------------------------------------------
If any chapter, section, or subsection of this chapter or the application of any chapter, section, or subsection to any person or circumstance is held invalid, the remainder of the provisions of this chapter shall be given effect without the invalid provision or application.  The provisions of this chapter are severable.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 31A - Chapter 16a - Risk Management and Own Risk and Solvency Assessment Act
********************************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16a-101 Title -- Scope.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16a-101(1): This chapter is known as the "Risk Management and Own Risk and Solvency Assessment Act."
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16a-101(2): 31A-16a-106 This chapter applies to an insurer domiciled in this state unless exempt pursuant to Section


Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16a-103 Risk management framework.
------------------------------------------------------------
An insurer shall maintain a risk management framework to assist the insurer with identifying, assessing, monitoring, managing, and reporting on its material and relevant risks. This requirement may be satisfied if the insurance group of which the insurer is a member maintains a risk management framework applicable to the operations of the insurer.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16b-108 Penalties.
--------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16b-108(1): An insurer or insurance group that, without just cause, fails to timely file a corporate governance annual disclosure as required in this chapter shall, after notice and hearing, pay a penalty of $10,000 for each day's delay, up to $300,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16b-108(2): Any penalty recovered by the commissioner under this section shall be deposited into the General Fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-16b-108(3): The commissioner may reduce a penalty under this section if the insurer or insurance group demonstrates to the commissioner that the imposition of the penalty would constitute a financial hardship to the insurer.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 31A - Chapter 17 - Determination of Financial Condition
***********************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-101 Scope.
---------------------------------------
Except as otherwise provided under this code, this chapter and the rules adopted to implement it apply to all insurers, including reinsurers, authorized to do business in this state.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-102 Standards for accounting rules.
----------------------------------------------------------------
When adopting accounting rules, the commissioner shall consider recommendations made by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners. Accounting rules shall follow generally accepted accounting principles, except as modified by statutory insurance accounting principles.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-203 Encumbering of assets.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-203(1): No domestic insurer may pledge, hypothecate, or otherwise encumber its assets to secure the debt, guaranty, or obligation of any other person. This prohibition does not apply to obligations of the insurer under surety bonds or insurance contracts issued in the regular course of business.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-203(2): No domestic insurer may pledge, hypothecate, or otherwise encumber its assets in an amount in excess of the amount of its capital and surplus, without the prior written consent of the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-203(3): (2) The commissioner may grant a domestic insurer an exception to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-203(4): Any person that accepts a pledge, hypothecation, or encumbrance of any asset of an insurer not in accordance with the terms and limitations of this section is considered to have accepted that asset subject to a superior, preferential, and perfected lien in favor of owners, beneficiaries, assignees, certificate holders, or third party claimants or beneficiaries of any insurance benefit or right arising out of and within the coverage of any insurance policy issued by the insurer.  The commissioner may bring or participate in an action in any court of competent jurisdiction to protect the interests of insureds or claimants under this section.

In valuing assets, the commissioner shall consider any method then current, formulated, or approved by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners.

The present value of future income derived from securities is determined by rule adopted by the commissioner.  A parent insurer may attribute value to a security of its subsidiary only if the parent insurer is being paid dividends or interest on the security, and only if the parent insurer can reasonably anticipate that dividends or interest will continue to be paid on the security.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-404.4 Transition -- Application to reinsurance agreement.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The amendments to this part made in

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-405 Fraternal rates and reserves.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-405(1): A fraternal may be organized for the transaction of business on a plan set forth in the contract which provides for sufficient contributions by each member each year to pay the member's share of the actual death claims of the year, through advance payments graded according to a mortality table approved by the commissioner, without any reserve, or with a reserve which may accumulate from overpayments of individual members.  If this type of reserve does accumulate, each member shall be informed each year of the member's credit and of the cost of the member's insurance.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-405(2): Each fraternal shall collect regular premiums for each coverage it provides at adequate rates that are approved by the commissioner or conform to standards set by rules adopted by the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-405(3): Chapter 5, Domestic Stock and Mutual Insurance Corporations; Chapter 5, Domestic Stock and Mutual Insurance Corporations The reserves of a fraternal are subject to the same requirements as those of


Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-406 Adjustment of reserves.
--------------------------------------------------------
The commissioner may order an insurer to adjust its reserves so the reserves bear a reasonable actuarial relationship to the insurer's obligations.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-407 Accounting for repurchased shares.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
When a corporation acquires its own shares under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-408 Title insurance reserves.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-408(1): In addition to an adequate reserve for outstanding losses, a title insurance company shall either:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-408(1)(a): maintain and segregate an unearned premium reserve fund of not less than 10 cents for each $1,000 face amount of retained liability under each title insurance contract or policy on a single insurance risk issued; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-408(1)(b): have the commissioner review and approve a contract of reinsurance applicable to the title insurance company's policies, which contract adequately covers the exposure or risk which the unearned premium reserve would serve.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-408(2): The fund shall be maintained for the protection of policyholders and is not subject to the claims of stockholders or creditors other than policyholders.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-408(3): The title insurance company may release the fund in accordance with the standards of the NAIC Accounting Practices and Procedures Manual.


Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-501 Standard Valuation Law -- Definitions.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-501(1): This part is known as the "Standard Valuation Law."
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-501(2): 31A-1-301; 31A-17-503(2); 31A-1-301; 31A-17-515; 31A-17-514 As used in this part, the following definitions apply on or after the operative date of the valuation manual:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-501(2)(a): 31A-1-301 Notwithstanding Section
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-501(2)(b): 31A-17-503(2) "Appointed actuary" means a qualified actuary who is appointed in accordance with the valuation manual to prepare the actuarial opinion required in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-501(2)(c): "Company" means an entity that:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-501(2)(c)(i): has written, issued, or reinsured a life insurance contract, accident and health insurance contract, or deposit-type contract in this state and has at least one such policy in force or on claim; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-501(2)(c)(ii): has written, issued, or reinsured a life insurance contract, accident and health insurance contract, or deposit-type contract in any state and is required to hold a certificate of authority to write life insurance, accident and health insurance, or deposit-type contracts in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-501(2)(d): "Deposit-type contract" means a contract that does not incorporate mortality or morbidity risks and as may be specified in the valuation manual.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-501(2)(e): 31A-1-301 Notwithstanding Section
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-501(2)(f): "Policyholder behavior" means an action that a policyholder, contract holder, or any other person with the right to elect options, such as a certificate holder, may take under a policy or contract subject to this part, including lapse, withdrawal, transfer, deposit, premium payment, loan, annuitization, or benefit elections prescribed by the policy or contract, but excluding events of mortality or morbidity that result in benefits prescribed in their essential aspects by the terms of the policy or contract.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-501(2)(g): 31A-17-515 "Principle-based valuation" means a reserve valuation that uses one or more methods or one or more assumptions determined by the insurer and is required to comply with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-501(2)(h): "Qualified actuary" means an individual who is qualified to sign the applicable statement of actuarial opinion in accordance with the American Academy of Actuaries qualification standards for actuaries signing the statements and who meets the requirements specified in the valuation manual.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-501(2)(i): "Tail risk" means a risk that occurs either when the frequency of low probability events is higher than expected under a normal probability distribution or when there are observed events of very significant size or magnitude.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-501(2)(j): 31A-17-514 "Valuation manual" means the manual of valuation instructions adopted in accordance with Section


Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-502 Reserve valuation.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-502(1): 31A-17-504; 31A-17-505; 31A-17-506; 31A-17-507; 31A-17-508; 31A-17-509; 31A-17-510; 31A-17-511; 31A-17-512; 31A-17-513; 31A-17-514; 31A-17-515; (1)(b)(i) The following apply to a policy or contract issued before the operative date of the valuation manual:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-502(1)(a): The commissioner shall annually value, or cause to be valued, the reserve liabilities, also called "reserves" in this part, for outstanding life insurance policies and annuity and pure endowment contracts, of every life insurance company doing business in this state, issued before the operative date of the valuation manual. In calculating the reserves, the commissioner may use group methods and approximate averages for fractions of a year or otherwise. In lieu of the valuation of the reserves required in this part of any foreign or alien company, the commissioner may accept any valuation made, or caused to be made, by the insurance supervisory official of any state or other jurisdiction when such valuation complies with the minimum standard provided in this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-502(1)(b): 31A-17-504; 31A-17-505; 31A-17-506; 31A-17-507; 31A-17-508; 31A-17-509; 31A-17-510; 31A-17-511; 31A-17-512; 31A-17-513; 31A-17-514; 31A-17-515; (1)(b)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-502(1)(b)(i): 31A-17-504; 31A-17-505; 31A-17-506; 31A-17-507; 31A-17-508; 31A-17-509; 31A-17-510; 31A-17-511; 31A-17-512; 31A-17-513 Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-502(1)(b)(ii): 31A-17-514; 31A-17-515; (1)(b)(i) Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-502(2): 31A-17-514; 31A-17-515 The following apply to a policy or contract issued on or after the operative date of the valuation manual:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-502(2)(a): The commissioner shall annually value, or cause to be valued, the reserve liabilities, also called "reserves" in this part, for an outstanding life insurance contract, annuity and pure endowment contract, accident and health contract, and deposit-type contract of every company issued on or after the operative date of the valuation manual.  In lieu of the valuation of the reserve liabilities required of a foreign or alien company, the commissioner may accept a valuation made, or caused to be made, by the insurance supervisory official of any state or other jurisdiction when the valuation complies with the minimum standard provided in this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-502(2)(b): 31A-17-514; 31A-17-515 Sections


Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503 Actuarial opinion of reserves.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(1): (1)(a); (1)(b); (1); 31A-2-308; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act; 63G-2-305; 63G-2-202(7)
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(1)(a): For an actuarial opinion before the operative date of the valuation manual, a life insurance company doing business in this state shall annually submit the opinion of a qualified actuary as to whether the reserves and related actuarial items held in support of the policies and contracts specified by the commissioner by rule are computed appropriately, are based on assumptions which satisfy contractual provisions, are consistent with prior reported amounts, and comply with applicable laws of this state. The commissioner by rule shall define the specifics of this opinion and add any other items considered to be necessary to its scope.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(1)(b): (1)(a) The following apply to the actuarial analysis of reserves and assets supporting reserves:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(1)(b)(i): (1)(a) A life insurance company, except as exempted by or pursuant to rule, shall also annually include in the opinion required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(1)(b)(ii): The commissioner may provide by rule for a transition period for establishing any higher reserves which the qualified actuary may consider necessary in order to render the opinion required by this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(1)(c): (1)(b) An opinion required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(1)(c)(i): A memorandum, in form and substance acceptable to the commissioner as specified by rule, shall be prepared to support each actuarial opinion.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(1)(c)(ii): If the insurance company fails to provide a supporting memorandum at the request of the commissioner within a period specified by rule or the commissioner determines that the supporting memorandum provided by the insurance company fails to meet the standards prescribed by the rule or is otherwise unacceptable to the commissioner, the commissioner may engage a qualified actuary at the expense of the company to review the opinion and the basis for the opinion and prepare such supporting memorandum as is required by the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(1)(d): (1); 31A-2-308; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act; 63G-2-305; 63G-2-202(7) An opinion subject to this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(1)(d)(i): The opinion shall be submitted with the annual statement reflecting the valuation of the reserve liabilities for each year ending on or after December 31, 1993.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(1)(d)(ii): The opinion shall apply to the business in force including individual and group health insurance plans, in form and substance acceptable to the commissioner as specified by rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(1)(d)(iii): The opinion shall be based on standards adopted from time to time by the Actuarial Standards Board and on such additional standards as the commissioner may by rule prescribe.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(1)(d)(iv): In the case of an opinion required to be submitted by a foreign or alien company, the commissioner may accept the opinion filed by that company with the insurance supervisory official of another state if the commissioner determines that the opinion reasonably meets the requirements applicable to a company domiciled in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(1)(d)(v): For the purposes of this section, "qualified actuary" means a member in good standing of the American Academy of Actuaries who meets the requirements set forth by department rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(1)(d)(vi): Except in cases of fraud or willful misconduct, the qualified actuary is not liable for damages to any person, other than the insurance company and the commissioner, for any act, error, omission, decision, or conduct with respect to the actuary's opinion.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(1)(d)(vii): 31A-2-308; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act Disciplinary action by the commissioner against the company or the qualified actuary shall be defined in rules by the commissioner consistent with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(1)(d)(viii): 63G-2-305; 63G-2-202(7)
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(1)(d)(viii)(A): 63G-2-305; 63G-2-202(7) Any memorandum in support of the opinion, and any other material provided by the company to the commissioner in connection with the opinion, are considered protected records under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(1)(d)(viii)(B): However, the memorandum or other material may otherwise be released by the commissioner with the written consent of the company, or to the American Academy of Actuaries upon request stating that the memorandum or other material is required for the purpose of professional disciplinary proceedings and setting forth procedures satisfactory to the commissioner for preserving the confidentiality of the memorandum or other material.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(1)(d)(viii)(C): Once any portion of the confidential memorandum is cited in its marketing or is cited before any governmental agency other than the department or is released to the news media, all portions of the memorandum are no longer confidential.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(2): (2)(a); (2)(b); (2); (2)(b); 31A-2-308; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act The following apply to an actuarial opinion of reserves after the operative date of the valuation manual:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(2)(a): A company with an outstanding life insurance contract, accident and health insurance contract, or deposit-type contract in this state and subject to rule made by the commissioner shall annually submit the opinion of the appointed actuary as to whether the reserves and related actuarial items held in support of the policies and contracts are computed appropriately, are based on assumptions that satisfy contractual provisions, are consistent with prior reported amounts, and comply with applicable laws of this state.  The valuation manual will prescribe the specifics of this opinion including any items considered to be necessary to its scope.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(2)(b): (2)(a) A company with an outstanding life insurance contract, accident and health insurance contract, or deposit-type contract in this state and subject to rule made by the commissioner, except as exempted in the valuation manual, shall also annually include in the opinion required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(2)(c): (2)(b) An opinion required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(2)(c)(i): A memorandum, in form and substance as specified in the valuation manual, and acceptable to the commissioner, shall be prepared to support each actuarial opinion.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(2)(c)(ii): If the insurance company fails to provide a supporting memorandum at the request of the commissioner within a period specified in the valuation manual or the commissioner determines that the supporting memorandum provided by the insurance company fails to meet the standards prescribed by the valuation manual or is otherwise unacceptable to the commissioner, the commissioner may engage a qualified actuary at the expense of the company to review the opinion and the basis for the opinion and prepare the supporting memorandum required by the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(2)(d): (2); (2)(b); 31A-2-308; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act An opinion subject to this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(2)(d)(i): The opinion shall be in form and substance as specified in the valuation manual and acceptable to the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(2)(d)(ii): The opinion shall be submitted with the annual statement reflecting the valuation of such reserve liabilities for each year ending on or after the operative date of the valuation manual.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(2)(d)(iii): (2)(b) The opinion shall apply to the policies and contracts subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(2)(d)(iv): The opinion shall be based on standards adopted from time to time by the Actuarial Standards Board or its successor, and on such additional standards as may be prescribed in the valuation manual.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(2)(d)(v): In the case of an opinion required to be submitted by a foreign or alien company, the commissioner may accept the opinion filed by that company with the insurance supervisory official of another state if the commissioner determines that the opinion reasonably meets the requirements applicable to a company domiciled in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(2)(d)(vi): Except in cases of fraud or willful misconduct, the appointed actuary may not be liable for damages to any person, other than the insurance company and the commissioner, for any act, error, omission, decision, or conduct with respect to the appointed actuary's opinion.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-503(2)(d)(vii): 31A-2-308; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act Disciplinary action by the commissioner against the company or the appointed actuary shall be defined in rules by the commissioner consistent with Section

Except as provided in SectionsUtah Code Annotated § 31A-17-504(1): 31A-22-408(6)(a); 31A-22-408(6)(a); 31A-22-408(6)(d); 31A-22-408(6)(d) For an ordinary policy of life insurance issued on the standard basis, excluding any accident and health and accidental death benefits in the policy, the Commissioner's 1941 Standard Ordinary Mortality Table for such policies issued before the operative date of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-504(1)(a): the Commissioner's 1980 Standard Ordinary Mortality Table;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-504(1)(b): at the election of the company for any one or more specified plans of life insurance, the Commissioner's 1980 Standard Ordinary Mortality Table with Ten-Year Select Mortality Factors; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-504(1)(c): any ordinary mortality table, adopted after 1980 by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, that is approved by rule made by the commissioner for use in determining the minimum standard of valuation for such policies.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-504(2): 31A-22-408(6)(c) For an industrial life insurance policy issued on the standard basis, excluding any accident and health and accidental death benefits in the policy, the 1941 Standard Industrial Mortality Table for the policy issued before the operative date of Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-504(3)(a): the 1937 Standard Annuity Mortality Table;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-504(3)(b): at the option of the company, the Annuity Mortality Table for 1949, Ultimate; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-504(3)(c): any modification of either of these tables approved by the commissioner.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-504(4): For group annuity and pure endowment contracts, excluding any accident and health and accidental death benefits in such policies:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-504(4)(a): the Group Annuity Mortality Table for 1951, any modification of such table approved by the commissioner; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-504(4)(b): at the option of the company, any of the tables or modifications of tables specified for individual annuity and pure endowment contracts.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-504(5)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-504(5)(a)(i): for a policy or contract issued on or after January 1, 1966, the tables of Period 2 disablement rates and the 1930 to 1950 termination rates of the 1952 Disability Study of the Society of Actuaries, with due regard to the type of benefit or any tables of disablement rates and termination rates adopted after 1980 by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, that are approved by rule made by the commissioner for use in determining the minimum standard of valuation for the policy;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-504(5)(a)(ii): for a policy or contract issued on or after January 1, 1961, and before January 1, 1966, either such tables or, at the option of the company, the Class (3) Disability Table (1926); and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-504(5)(a)(iii): for a policy issued before January 1, 1961, the Class (3) Disability Table (1926).
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-504(5)(b): (5) A table described in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-504(6): For accidental death benefits in or supplementary to policies issued on or after January 1, 1966, the 1959 Accidental Death Benefits Table or any accidental death benefits table adopted after 1980 by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, that is approved by rule made by the commissioner for use in determining the minimum standard of valuation for such policies, for policies issued on or after January 1, 1961, and before January 1, 1966, either such table or, at the option of the company, the Inter-Company Double Indemnity Mortality Table, and for policies issued before January 1, 1961, the Inter-Company Double Indemnity Mortality Table. Either table shall be combined with a mortality table for calculating the reserves for life insurance policies.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-504(7): For group life insurance, life insurance issued on the substandard basis and other special benefits: such tables as may be approved by the commissioner.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-506(3)(b)(ii)(A)(III): as an immediate life annuity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-506(3)(b)(ii)(A)(IV): no withdrawal permitted.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-506(3)(b)(ii)(B): 
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-506(3)(b)(ii)(B)(I): Plan Type B: Before expiration of the interest rate guarantee, policyholder withdraw funds only:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-506(3)(b)(ii)(B)(I)(Aa): with an adjustment to reflect changes in interest rates or asset values since receipt of the funds by the insurance company;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-506(3)(b)(ii)(B)(I)(Bb): without such adjustment but in installments over five years or more; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-506(3)(b)(ii)(B)(I)(Cc): no withdrawal permitted.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-506(3)(b)(ii)(B)(II): At the end of interest rate guarantee, funds may be withdrawn without such adjustment in a single sum or installments over less than five years.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-506(3)(b)(ii)(C): Plan Type C: Policyholder may withdraw funds before expiration of interest rate guarantee in a single sum or installments over less than five years either:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-506(3)(b)(ii)(C)(I): without adjustment to reflect changes in interest rates or asset values since receipt of the funds by the insurance company; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-506(3)(b)(ii)(C)(II): subject only to a fixed surrender charge stipulated in the contract as a percentage of the fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-506(3)(b)(iii): A company may elect to value guaranteed interest contracts with cash settlement options and annuities with cash settlement options on either an issue year basis or on a change in fund basis.  Guaranteed interest contracts with no cash settlement options and other annuities with no cash settlement options shall be valued on an issue year basis.  As used in this section, an issue year basis of valuation refers to a valuation basis under which the interest rate used to determine the minimum valuation standard for the entire duration of the annuity or guaranteed interest contract is the calendar year valuation interest rate for the year of issue or year of purchase of the annuity or guaranteed interest contract, and the change in fund basis of valuation refers to a valuation basis under which the interest rate used to determine the minimum valuation standard applicable to each change in the fund held under the annuity or guaranteed interest contract is the calendar year valuation interest rate for the year of the change in the fund.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-508 Reserve valuation method -- Annuity and pure endowment benefits.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-508(1): This section shall apply to all annuity and pure endowment contracts other than group annuity and pure endowment contracts purchased under a retirement plan or plan of deferred compensation, established or maintained by an employer, including a partnership or sole proprietorship, or by an employee organization, or by both, other than a plan providing individual retirement accounts or individual retirement annuities under Section 408, Internal Revenue Code.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-508(2): Reserves according to the commissioner's annuity reserve method for benefits under annuity or pure endowment contracts, excluding any accident and health and accidental death benefits in such contracts, shall be the greatest of the respective excesses of the present values, at the date of valuation, of the future guaranteed benefits, including guaranteed nonforfeiture benefits, provided for by such contracts at the end of each respective contract year, over the present value, at the date of valuation, of any future valuation considerations derived from future gross considerations, required by the terms of such contract, that become payable prior to the end of such respective contract year.  The future guaranteed benefits shall be determined by using the mortality table, if any, and the interest rate, or rates, specified in such contracts for determining guaranteed benefits.  The valuation considerations are the portions of the respective gross considerations applied under the terms of such contracts to determine nonforfeiture values.

--------------------------------------------------------------

Reserves for any category of policies, contracts, or benefits as established by the commissioner, issued on or after January 1, 1994, may be calculated, at the option of the company, according to any standards which produce greater aggregate reserves for such category than those calculated according to the minimum standard provided in this part, but the rate or rates of interest used for policies and contracts, other than annuity and pure endowment contracts, may not be greater than the corresponding rate or rates of interest used in calculating any nonforfeiture benefits provided in the policy or contract.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-512(2): be computed by a method which is consistent with the principles of this part, as determined by rules promulgated by the commissioner.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-515 Requirements of a principle-based valuation.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-515(1): A company shall establish reserves using a principle-based valuation that meets the following conditions for a policy or contract as specified in the valuation manual:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-515(1)(a): A company shall quantify the benefits and guarantees, and the funding, associated with the policy or contract and the policy's or contract's risks at a level of conservatism that reflects:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-515(1)(a)(i): conditions that include unfavorable events that have a reasonable probability of occurring during the lifetime of the policies or contracts; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-515(1)(a)(ii): for polices or contracts with significant tail risk, conditions appropriately adverse to quantify the tail risk.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-515(1)(b): The company shall incorporate assumptions, risk analysis methods, and financial models and management techniques that are consistent with, but not necessarily identical to, those used within the company's overall risk assessment process, while recognizing potential differences in financial reporting structures and any prescribed assumptions or methods.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-515(1)(c): The company shall incorporate assumptions that are derived in one of the following manners:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-515(1)(c)(i): the assumption is prescribed in the valuation manual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-515(1)(c)(ii): for assumptions that are not prescribed, the assumptions shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-515(1)(c)(ii)(A): be established using the company's available experience, to the extent it is relevant and statistically credible; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-515(1)(c)(ii)(B): to the extent that company data is not available, relevant, or statistically credible, be established using other relevant, statistically credible experience.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-515(1)(d): The company shall provide margins for uncertainty including adverse deviation and estimation error, such that the greater the uncertainty the larger the margin and resulting reserve.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-515(2): A company using a principle-based valuation for one or more policies or contracts subject to this section as specified in the valuation manual shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-515(2)(a): establish procedures for corporate governance and oversight of the actuarial valuation function consistent with those described in the valuation manual;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-515(2)(b): provide to the commissioner and the board of directors an annual certification of the effectiveness of the internal controls with respect to the principle-based valuation:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-515(2)(b)(i): which controls shall be designed to assure that all material risks inherent in the liabilities and associated assets subject to such valuation are included in the valuation, and that valuations are made in accordance with the valuation manual; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-515(2)(b)(ii): the certification shall be based on the controls in place as of the end of the preceding calendar year; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-515(2)(c): develop, and file with the commissioner upon request, a principle-based valuation report that complies with standards prescribed in the valuation manual.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-515(3): A principle-based valuation may include a prescribed formulaic reserve component.


Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-516 Experience reporting for policies in force on or after the operative date of the valuation manual.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A company shall submit mortality, morbidity, policyholder behavior, or expense experience and other data as prescribed in the valuation manual.

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-601 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-601(1): 31A-17-602(5) "Adjusted RBC report" means an RBC report that has been adjusted by the commissioner in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-601(2): "Corrective order" means an order issued by the commissioner specifying corrective action that the commissioner determines is required.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-601(3): Chapter 7, Nonprofit Health Service Insurance Corporations; Chapter 8, Health Maintenance Organizations and Limited Health Plans "Health organization" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-601(3)(a): Chapter 7, Nonprofit Health Service Insurance Corporations; Chapter 8, Health Maintenance Organizations and Limited Health Plans an entity that is authorized under
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-601(3)(b): that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-601(3)(b)(i): a health maintenance organization;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-601(3)(b)(ii): a limited health service organization;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-601(3)(b)(iii): a dental or vision plan;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-601(3)(b)(iv): a hospital, medical, and dental indemnity or service corporation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-601(3)(b)(v): other managed care organization.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-601(4): "Life or accident and health insurer" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-601(4)(a): an insurance company licensed to write life insurance, accident and health insurance, or both; or
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-601(4)(b): a licensed property casualty insurer writing only disability insurance.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-601(5): "Property and casualty insurer" means any insurance company licensed to write lines of insurance other than life but does not include a monoline mortgage guaranty insurer, financial guaranty insurer, or title insurer.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-601(6): "RBC" means risk-based capital.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-601(7): "RBC instructions" means the RBC report including the National Association of Insurance Commissioner's risk-based capital instructions that govern the year for which an RBC report is prepared.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-601(8): "RBC level" means an insurer's or health organization's authorized control level RBC, company action level RBC, mandatory control level RBC, or regulatory action level RBC.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-601(8)(a): "Authorized control level RBC" means the number determined under the risk-based capital formula in accordance with the RBC instructions;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-601(8)(b): "Company action level RBC" means the product of 2.0 and its authorized control level RBC;
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-601(8)(c): "Mandatory control level RBC" means the product of .70 and the authorized control level RBC; and
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-601(8)(d): "Regulatory action level RBC" means the product of 1.5 and its authorized control level RBC.
Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-601(9): 31A-17-603(2); (9)(a)

Utah Code Annotated § 31A-17-602(1)(b): file its RBC report with the insurance commissioner in any state in which the insurer or health organization is authorized to do business, if the insurance commissioner of that state notifies the insurer or health organization of its request in writing, in which case the insurer or health organization may file its RBC report not later than the later of:
